question: Dewey. I'm the one asking the riddle. I already know the answer. I don't getta guess. Although... We could say if I get to five hundred bounces and no one gets the riddle, I get the pot. And I know what you're thinking. It's an impossible riddle. Well, It's not. It's an easy riddle. And if somehow by the grace of fluke luck I win, and you all don't agree it was an easy riddle, hell, I'll refund your money. Okay, a man's driving down the road with his son and they get in a crash. Two ambulances come and take the man and his son to different hospitals. Son goes into the operating room, the doctor looks at him and says, 'I can't operate on this boy. He's my son.' How's that possible? The clock's ticking boys...
answer: Father didn't sneak back in, right? He's still at the other hospital?

question: It ain't 'Star Trek,' Earl. No one beamed him aboard.
answer: Well... if the father married the son's daughter --

question: The doctor's a woman. The doctor is the son's mother. Feminists pose the riddle to reveal how deeply our sexual stereotypes run. I take it you're a feminist?
answer: Ma'am, I've been called a lot of things -- but no one's ever saddled me with that one.

question: You might try being saddled sometime -- the smell of leather, the sting of a whip...
answer: I'm just a humble golf pro...

question: You're Roy McAvoy the golf pro? I pictured something... different. I have a seven o'clock lesson.
answer: I thought I had a Doctor Griswold The first thing you gotta learn about this game, Doc, is it ain't about hitting a little white ball into some yonder hole. It's about inner demons and self-doubt and human frailty and overcoming all that crap. So... what kinda doctor'd you say you were?

question: I'm a psychologist -- in layman's terms call me a neo-Jungian, post- modern Freudian, holistic secularist.
answer: Damn.

question: Inner demons and human frailty are my life's work. I used to practice in El Paso but I've moved here now...
answer: What're those?

question: I ordered these from the Golf Channel.
answer: That stuff's a waste of money.

question: I'm sure there are excesses and repetitions here, but I believe in the gathering of knowledge and I figured, well, there must be some truths about the golf swing illustrated by these devices -- and that you'd help me sort through it. I have dozens of golf videotapes, too... And a golf watch.
answer: Take it off. All of it. Now! You're a smart woman, for Chrissakes -- don't you know the work of charlatans when you see it?

question: No. I can always tell when someone is lying to himself, but I'm quite susceptible and frequently wrong when that person lies to me. That stuff cost me over 200 dollars --
answer: Then it's 200 dollars of shit... Go ahead. Take a swing.

question: Aw, fuck...
answer: Well, you talk like a golfer --

question: Shit.
answer: 'Fuck...' 'Shit...' these are highly technical golf terms and you're using them on your first lesson -- this is promising.

question: Awright, wise ass, show me.
answer: Something like that.

question: Impressive. Y'know, I tend to process things verbally. Can you break down into words how you did that?
answer: 'What is the golf swing?' -- by Roy McAvoy. The golf swing is a poem. Sometimes a love sonnet and sometimes a Homerian epic -- it is organic and of a piece, yet it breaks down into elegant stanzas and quatrains. The critical opening phrase of this song is the grip, in which the hands unite to form a single unit by the simple overlap of the smallest finger... ... held lightly, a conductor's

question: A nod to the gods?
answer: To the gods, yes... that he is fallible. As the weight shifts back to the left pulled now by powers inside the earth -- it's alive, this swing, a living sculpture -- and down through contact, always down, into terra firma, striking the ball crisply -- with character -- a tuning fork goes off in your heart, your balls -- such a pure feeling is the well-struck golf shot -- And then the follow through to finish, always on line -- The reverse 'C' of the Golden Bear, the steelworker's power and brawn of Carl Sandburg's Arnold Palmer, the da Vinci of Hogan, the unfinished symphony of Roy McAvoy.

question: What? What's unfinished?
answer: I have a short follow through -- my swing can look unfinished.

question: Why?
answer: Some say it's because that's the best way to play through the winds of West Texas... and some say it's because I never finish anything. You can decide. The point is every finishing position is unique as if that is the signature left to the artist, the warrior athlete who,

question: Jeez Louise...
answer: There is only one other acceptable theory of how to hit a golf ball.

question: I'm afraid to ask. What's the other theory?
answer: Grip it and rip it.

question: While I appreciate your poetic sensibility, Mr. McAvoy --
answer: Call me Roy, Molly...

question: Call me Dr. Griswold... Roy... but at this point I think I'm more of the 'grip it and rip it' school. Hand me the driver.
answer: Waggle it, Doc, don't forget to waggle. Waggle... the club head... ... it's a little relaxing ritual... Let the Big Dog eat!

question: What Big Dog?
answer: The driver, the number one wood --

question: It's metal.
answer: Yeah, woods are metal -- don't worry about it -- and the driver's known as the Big Dog and I'm just saying to turn him loose, let 'er rip, let the Big Dog eat!

question: Oh. This is, without a doubt, the stupidest, silliest, most idiotic grotesquery masquerading as a game that has ever been invented.
answer: Yes, ma'am, that's why I love it. And if you hit one good shot -- if that tuning fork rings in your loin -- you can't wait to get back.

question: I think the Big Dog ate something.
answer: Did the tuning fork ring in your loin?

question: I wouldn't go that far.
answer: Always quit on a good shot. We'll call that lesson number one...

question: If you're such a legendary striker of the golf ball as everyone says, then why are you, at your age, out here in the middle of nowhere operating a barely solvent establishment, ducking the I.R.S., collecting a few pathetic dollars to buy your next sixpack -- when you're capable of so much more?
answer: Perhaps I'm chocked full of inner demons?

question: No, you're chocked full of bullshit -- Same time next week?
answer: What did you mean I should try 'being saddled' sometime? Were you being literal or was that some kind of Freudian type deal? Molly? Doctor? What kind of saddle?

question: Twelve thousand.
answer: Hundred.

question: Thousand.
answer: Hundred.

question: You said to shoot the wad.
answer: I said get even, Pod. I didn't say shoot the wad. We better see that three dog rolling on his ass.

question: So, Roy, you were saying you felt a little flutter for this doctor lady?
answer: Yes, I was saying that... just before I was interrupted by... bankruptcy -- a development that the 'Doctor Lady,' as you call her,

question: We lost everything, boss! We owe Doreen twelve thousand bucks!
answer: I think I been dating too many big-haired blondes.

question: Them big-haired blondes are a lot smarter 'n us... ... how we gonna pay her?
answer: You underestimate me, Romes.

question: It's a bad habit I picked up from knowing you so long.
answer: I'm sure she is... Busy man, Courtenay, busy man -- Hiya, honey -- lookin' sweet... Doreen...

question: I know you're going to pay me. Y'know I finally got rid of the leopard suit thing -- it was so retro, y'know... it's not easy being a post-modern stripper... So... twelve big ones?
answer: There. With equity and inventory it's worth twelve grand... more or less.

question: This is how you think you can settle up? By deeding me your driving range?
answer: Only on condition you don't sell right away, and me'n Romeo keep our jobs.

question: What in the world would I want with your stupid driving range?
answer: Equity, inventory, cash flow... not to mention an enhanced stature in the community, and prepaid membership in the Salome Chamber of Commerce.

question: What are your labor costs? Payroll, Roy. What do you pay
answer: Let's see... the tractor kid gets five bucks an hour. Romeo, he gets ten cash --

question: What do you pay yourself?
answer: Myself?

question: To hit golf balls all day... when you're not breaking for beers or corn dogs or to gather the guys and lay bets on which crow flies off the fence next.
answer: You're referring to my managerial salary?

question: (with horror, inside
answer: I still got two grand to pay off. And I can't see my new salary of seven bucks an hour plus lessons getting it done.

question: But your clubs are your livelihood.
answer: Well the hood ain't too lively at the moment. Whoever it is, tell 'em I'm in Houston on business.

question: David Simms! What you doing in town?
answer: Romeo! It's been awhile. Is Tin Cup around?

question: He's on business in Houston... You supposed to be out playin' on the golf tour.
answer: Well, you tell him I'm in town for my big charity best-ball tournament, and I got a spot for him when he comes back from... whatever.

question: You got a spot for Tin Cup? I thought you hated him.
answer: Romeo! You wound me. I'm fond of the guy, going way back to our days at University of Houston, when we won all those titles together.

question: He says he carried you on his back.
answer: I didn't have much craft back then -- just a little native ability. Roy's a great ball- striker....

question: Why you here?
answer: I want to win my own tournament, and he can help me if we can manage to behave like grownups together. Tell him that.

question: I want to win my own tournament, and he can help me if we can manage to behave like grownups together. Tell him that.
answer: What's the catch?

question: There is no catch. I put together a tournament with an elite field and a half-million dollar purse, and I'm tired of seeing all the money head out of town.
answer: Then make more birdies.

question: I need you on my team.
answer: You ain't that friendly a guy...

question: We're playing Cottonwood where you once shot fifty-nine, where you can shoot sixty-five in your sleep 'cuz you know every bump on every fairway, every subtle break on every green --
answer: You an' me --

question: Me an' you -- like the old days.
answer: ... Well, put 'er there, partner! These two homeboys are gonna show the world what golf in West Texas is all about!

question: I can't bring a guy in off the street to play in my tournament. It's a big-time event, corporate sponsors, thirty dollar tickets... I got a network to cover --
answer: (interrupting,

question: I'll pay you a hundred for the loop, five percent of any earnings --
answer: Get the hell outta here! Take your goddamn color coordinated corporate sponsored soul and get outta here.

question: I could.
answer: I gotta hand it to you, Roy. For fifteen holes you've seemed to grasp the concept here

question: Five percent of your earnings does numb the gag reflex.
answer: Give me the seven iron. I'm laying up.

question: You can make that shot.
answer: The smart play's to lay up.

question: These fans didn't pay thirty bucks to watch a tour star lay up on a short par five.
answer: I'm sitting on a two shot lead with three to go, and my partner's in his pocket. Suddenly, par's a good number. Gimme the seven Iron.

question: No way. You're going for the green. These fans paid good money to see golf shots they can't hit, not golf shots they feel shitty about themselves for having to hit. Thirteen years on tour and you're still a pussy. Hit the fucking one iron, Dave.
answer: Thirteen years in a driving range and you still think this game's about your testosterone count.

question: Two-fifteen to carry, and the tour star's laying up.
answer: But if you're gonna editorialize, do it on the other side of the ropes. I got no qualms about firing your ass right here, right now.

question: Balls versus brains, Roy. You hit that shot, just keep walking, 'cuz your ass is fired.
answer: How you gonna fire me in front of all these people? Especially when I knock it on the green.

question: Take a hike, Roy -- the loop's over.
answer: You can't fire me. How can you fire me? I just knocked it stiff from two fifty. Gimme that bag.

question: Security!
answer: What about my money?

question: If I had it all to do over, I'd still hit that shot.
answer: The look comes over your face, you would bury yourself alive to prove you can handle a shovel.

question: You know why I'd still hit that shot?
answer: 'Cuz it's the only way you can beat David Simms. 'Cuz you never got over that he is on tour and you are not. 'Cuz you get that look on your face...

question: No... I'd hit it again because that shot was a defining moment. And when a defining moment comes along you define the moment or the moment defines you. I did not shrink from the challenge. I rose to it.
answer: 1981, Fort Washington Golf Club, Fresno, California, final round of the Tour Qualifying School...

question: I was playing to win.
answer: A defining moment when you tried to hit the same impossible cut

question: Greatness courts failure, Romeo. That's why most people, in their whole lives, never ever reach for the brass ring, never know when to dig deep and try for the impossible shot...
answer: You're right about that, boss, but sometimes... sometimes... par is good enough to win.

question: The DieHard/West Texas Calcutta, the Duvall County Boys Club Pro/ Scratch, Woody's Steak House One Club Scramble... what do I want with all these entry forms?
answer: It's a business proposition. I'm offering you my winnings from all them tournaments this summer.

question: In exchange for what?
answer: My driving range back.

question: Roy, I'm not as dumb as my hair makes me look.
answer: They ain't all strictly minor league. One of 'em pays almost two grand! Now wait, Doreen. You gotta do the math, and you gotta look at how good I'm playing. I hit the shot of the tournament at the best-ball. They put it on national TV.

question: I saw.
answer: And what does that tell you? And what does that tell you?

question: It tells me you took an unauthorized day off. Next time it happens, you're fired. In the meantime, I'm putting in a time clock.
answer: I'm not punching in no time Am I early?

question: I'm not punching in no time Am I early?
answer: Mr. McAvoy, I can appreciate that you have a fairly laid-back, relaxed lifestyle -- but I have hours to keep.

question: A former paramour once ascribed my fluid sense of time to being born under the sign of Pisces -- something about floating through the universe --
answer: You amuse me, Roy. But I'm the only woman in America born after World War II who thinks astrology is a crock of shit. Now let's see if the Big Dog'll eat.

question: Waggle.
answer: I'm waggling...

question: Set up to the ball like I showed you last time. Quit trying to wring that club's neck, Molly. Show it a little warmth and compassion... Remember, this game's about trust and touch and letting go. So while I'm subtly enhancing your technical prospects, why don't you tell me all about your personal life...
answer: It's none of your fucking business, Roy.

question: Not him... He's taking her to Miami for the fucking Doral! How am I supposed to compete with that?
answer: Man, you are having a bad week.

question: She must think I'm such a nothing, such a loser... a lousy driving range pro living in a Winnebago, making five bucks an hour plus lessons.
answer: She don't know you live in a Winnebago.

question: Well, she sure as hell knows I ain't taking her to no Doral for massages and mimosas all weekend. I gotta do something with my life. I gotta rise to a level worthy of the women that think I'm a joke.
answer: Well... you could go out and win The Open.

question: Romeo, that idea has promise.
answer: I was joking.

question: I ain't.
answer: We talking about the same tournament? The U.S. Open? The Biggest golf tournament in the world?

question: Not just the biggest golf Tournament in the world; the most democratic.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I mean it's open. Anyone's got a shot at it. You just gotta get past a local and a sectional qualifier, and unlike Doral or Colonial or the A.T.T., they can't keep you out. They can't ask you if you're a garbageman or a bean- picker or a driving range pro whose check is signed by a stripper. You qualify, you're in.
answer: And then you pay out of your own pocket to go there and get all nervous and intimidated --

question: Who's intimidated? I just told you I'm gonna win the damn thing!
answer: You don't got the game.

question: I got every shot in the book.
answer: I said you don't got the game. The mental game. The head game.

question: You suggesting I err on the side of excess?
answer: You always go out to shoot zero. Sometimes you pull it off. But you can't play like that at the Open. You win by taking what the course gives you. You win by being humble, which you aren't, and patient, which you never will

question: Well, since you're the authority, How'd you like to teach me how to be what I ain't and never will be?
answer: You don't ever listen to me.

question: This time'll be different. I promise.
answer: I don't know, man. Right now you don't even got the money to get your clubs out of hock.

question: Yeah, well... my sticks may be in a pawn shop, but I got a rake and a hoe at the range.
answer: Let me get this straight -- you're going to play me for four hundred dollars with those?

question: And I'll give ya two a side... I got the title to my car as collateral.
answer: I'm not interested in that piece of shit.

question: That's cuz you think of it as transportation, Boone. Think of it as bragging rights. Think of yourself sitting around the bar crowing to your buddies about the Cadillac you won off Tin Cup McAvoy. They'll forget all about the Winnebago you lost to me.
answer: No mullies, no gimmes, no bumping the ball -- Nutted it.

question: I'll be playing a Pink Lady today.
answer: That little pink fag ball supposed to rattle me?

question: Not unless I knock it by you. Yep, I caught this thing way the Hell on the toe.
answer: Drive for show, putt for dough, big shot.

question: Front left bunker -- plugged lie.
answer: I want to see a legitimate swing. No scooping.

question: Stand, please. Gallery, please, stand. I'll finish.
answer: Get the hell off my course.

question: Listen, swami, your job is to teach me patience and humility, not to advise me on my love life.
answer: No. My job is to get your head straight so you can qualify for The Open, much less win it. To get your head straight you got to forget about the doctor lady.

question: Not all my thinking occurs below the belt. I actually stand for a few things beside where my next romantic interlude is coming from.
answer: Then you got no problem telling the doctor lady you can't teach her no more till after the Open.

question: That would make an issue of something that ain't an issue. Besides, I'm focused. I mean, this is my quest!
answer: Ahhh... your quest... chingaso...

question: This is where I stand up for all the little guys everywhere who've had their fill of soulless robots like David Simms --
answer: He may be a soulless robot but he's a rich, happy soulless robot with a beautiful doctor lady girlfriend who's got you by the huevos -- Besides, how is getting into the U.S. Open gonna change what she thinks about you?

question: It'll prove to her that I'm not who she thinks I am.
answer: But you are who she thinks you are! Look, I don't bet on a horse with a hard-on.

question: Hard-on?! Hard-on?! Hard-on?! Here, touch me, feel -- I don't feel nothing! Here!
answer: Hey, hey... shit... cool it...

question: Man, ever since I let her dump my ass she just can't resist kicking me in it.
answer: Maybe you should treat her more like a lady.

question: After she ran off with that Dallas banker?
answer: She did that after you let her dump you. It wouldn't kill you just once to tell her she's beautiful, she can dance, she's

question: Romeo... are you sweet on Doreen?
answer: No more'n you are for that doctor lady.

question: Great, Romeo, just great... just when I need you to be my friend and coach, you go get all gooey about one of my ex-girlfriends who just happens to be our boss.
answer: Anybody comes to me for help on their love life about women is already too far gone.

question: I don't recall asking you for advice. Women are tougher to figure out than a feathered one iron from a tight lie --
answer: Actually if you open the club face a hair and play it off your back foot --

question: Shut up, Romeo... I wasn't really seeking golf tips...
answer: It's all I'm good for -- but you can count on me for that, at least.

question: How far off the back foot?
answer: 'Bout three balls...

question: I'm ready to charge forth in pursuit of my mythic destiny and I can't get time off work to do it.
answer: I'm no expert, but it seems to me that the `pursuit of a person's mythic destiny' is not the sort of thing that a person needs to get off a five dollar an hour job in order to do...

question: I'm stuck. Buried. My life's a plugged lie in a kakuyi bunker with a tight pin position on a green with a stimp meter reading of thirteen. I need help. I need advice. I need counsel... I need a shrink.
answer: You don't know no shrinks.

question: I know one.
answer: Not the doctor lady?

question: Why not?
answer: You can't ask advice about the woman you're trying to hose from the woman you're trying to hose!

question: Hose?! Hose?! Get your mouth outta the gutter! This is a matter of the heart! I didn't do anything!
answer: I know... I know... wait in there. Roy... are you okay?

question: I need therapy.
answer: Obviously.

question: What do I do? I mean... to do it ... therapy... I mean, how do I start doing... it.
answer: In parlance you might understand, just kick back and let the Big Dog eat.

question: Okay, okay, let 'er rip... Suppose there's this guy. He's standing on the shore of a big, wide river. And the river's fulla all manner of disaster, like alligators and piranhas and currents and eddies, and most people won't even go down there to dip a toe. But on the other side of the river's a million dollars, and on this side of the river there's a rowboat. I guess my question's this
answer: He's an idiot.

question: No. He's a hell of a swimmer, see. His problem's more like... why's he always gotta rise to the challenge?
answer: He's a juvenile idiot.

question: You don't understand what I mean by the river.
answer: We're talking about you and what you like to call your inner demons, Roy, that human frailty you like to blather about, not some mytho-poetic metaphor you come up with in a feeble and transparent effort to do yourself credit.

question: Y'mean you're gonna make me feel lousy? I came here to feel better -- what kinda therapy is this?
answer: You don't have any inner demons. What you have is inner crapola, inner debris -- garbage, loose wires, horseshit in staggering amounts.

question: I ain't just some jerk driving- range pro who drinks too much booze and eats too few vegetables.
answer: You're being defensive -- cut to the chase and tell me why you're here.

question: Well... I'm smitten with a woman.
answer: That's good. Is she smitten with you?

question: Not yet.
answer: Have you asked her out?

question: She's seeing a guy. I don't know how serious it is, but the guy's a real horse's ass, in my opinion...
answer: If you shared your heart with this woman -- maybe asked her out to dinner -- then it would force these issues out in the open.

question: I'm afraid she'll say no.
answer: Ahh... so what you're saying is that all your speeches about swimming across the shark infested waters are really just about your golf game -- not about your personal life.

question: Christ, I didn't know we were gonna get into my personal life!
answer: This is therapy!

question: Well, jeez, I know, but I didn't think it was that kind of therapy...
answer: What were you expecting? Ann Landers?

question: Yeah.
answer: Look, it's rather simple. Those risks that you love to take on the golf course, the risks you talk so passionately and poetically about -- you need to apply those risks to your personal life with the same passion.

question: I should ask this woman out.
answer: Yes!

question: I should risk coming right over the top and snap-hooking it out of bounds left.
answer: Yes!

question: Risk hitting it a little thin and --
answer: For Godsakes, Roy, that's enough!

question: Right. Sorry.
answer: S'okay... Look, just walk up to this woman, wherever she is, look her in the eye with those big beautiful green eyes of yours, let down your guard and don't try to be smooth or cool or whatever -- just be honest and take the risk -- you can do it!

question: Dr. Griswold -- I think I'm in
answer: What?!

question: From the moment I first saw you I knew I was through with bar girls and strippers and motorcycle chicks, and when you started talking I was smitten and I'm smitten more every day I think about you -- and the fact that you know I'm full of crapola only makes you more attractive to me because usually I can bullshit people but I can't bullshit you and in addition, most women I'm thinking about how to get into their pants from Day One but with you I'm just thinking about how to get into your heart --
answer: My God...

question: Stunned, eh? So what about dinner and we can talk about `us' and if we have a future and how to drop that horse's ass boyfriend of yours --
answer: Roy, slow down --

question: Hey! I just hit a eight degree driver off a cart path here, I'm staring eagle in the face --
answer: This is a terrible mistake!

question: I'm acting from the heart so I can't make a mistake?! Right?
answer: Wrong. Aw, shit... I am one horrible shrink... jeez... I didn't know you were talking about me.

question: Would your advice have been different?
answer: Session's over. You better leave.

question: I'm gonna qualify for the U.S. Open and kick your boyfriend's ass.
answer: Please leave.

question: Whatever you think of me, you should know that your boyfriend hates old people, children, and dogs. Dollar bills... Dollar bills...
answer: How'd it go with the doctor lady, boss?

question: If she was a par three, I'd'a made a nine.
answer: Stroke and distance, eh?

question: Thanks, boys -- a man couldn't have better friends. Now move the hell back and shut the fuck up. You're messing up my concentration. Debt collection? Process server?
answer: God, you've got a beautiful swing --

question: -- And big, beautiful green eyes -- I'm a beautiful guy.
answer: I came here to apologize.

question: For what?
answer: Well, I counseled you, you did exactly what I said, and I just... poured cold water over your effort. I didn't get it. I'm a terrible shrink, probably... I should've never got out of real estate -- actually I should never have left Ohio for that cowboy in Armarillo -- have you ever been to Amarillo?

question: A cowboy?
answer: It's not as romantic when you're actually with one -- a wrangler, y'know -- so of course the oil man in Dallas looked great after that -- I don't know what I was thinking... That's when I went to the gulf and ended up in, well, trailer sales and then all those condos in Corpus Christi -- the bottom fell outta the market and I needed a new gig --

question: A new gig?
answer: Therapy. I took all the classes.

question: I got a little carried away, I guess. I shoulda just layed up, made my par, and moved on.
answer: Look, I want to propose something -- as long as you understand this is professional -- we're not going out together --

question: Tee it up.
answer: I can help you with the mental aspects of the game. You've got Romeo to be your swing doctor, I can be your head doctor.

question: But you said you were a lousy shrink?
answer: Well, yeah... I'll improve.

question: I got no money to pay for you.
answer: I'll trade my services for golf lessons and help you through the qualifying. If you get into the Open, well, you're on your own.

question: You'll be with David.
answer: Yeah...

question: How ya feelin', boss?
answer: I'm feelin' like par's a bad score, podnuh -- fifty-eight's within the realm!

question: Jesus, the doctor lady's here --
answer: Didn't I tell ya? She's gonna be your guru partner. You handle my swing mechanics and she handles my brain mechanics.

question: Long as you keep your dick out of it --
answer: Me an' the 'big guy' have an understanding. He's gonna lie low till I get in the Open -- then... then...

question: The Big Dog'll eat?
answer: The Big Dog'll hunt, that's for sure...

question: Looks like we partners, Dr. Molly
answer: I just have to help him keep his head on straight --

question: If you can, you be the first.
answer: He does have the occasional tendency towards self-destruction it seems.

question: Good. 'Cause it's his best side...
answer: Dollar bills... Nutted it... Ben Hogan? Who's he?

question: They bugging you, boss -- I can shut 'em up?
answer: The way I'm swinging today,

question: I think two iron's safer.
answer: I said I want the Big Dog.

question: Tight par five, out of bounds left... you don't want to hit driver.
answer: I'm not going left of those trees. I'm going over those trees... with a little draw. That way I get home in two. That way I'm putting for eagle.

question: You don't need eagle to qualify! You need to get used to playing smart -- no mistakes wins the Open.
answer: Qualify? I want the course record! Now gimme the lumber!

question: You not going to listen to me? You don't care I'm trying to help? You think I'm full of shit?
answer: I think I'm gonna get penalized for slow play if you don't give me that fucking driver.

question: You a head case, boss, always were, always will be.
answer: Then let's ask the head doctor. Dr. Griswold? Dr. Griswold, should I hit the Big Dog or the two?

question: Ha! Gimme the driver and shut up.
answer: ... Go ahead. Hit the driver.

question: I changed my mind. Gimme the three wood.
answer: You can't clear the dogleg with a three wood.

question: How'd I do, Doc?
answer: You failed miserably.

question: What?! I parred the back nine with a seven iron, I qualified for the regionals, I --
answer: Your job is not just to qualify for the Open, it's to prepare for the Open. My job is to help you prepare.

question: You said to 'trust my feelings'!
answer: I didn't know you felt like breaking all the clubs in your bag.

question: From what I understand, the U.S. Open is the most difficult golf tournament in the world played under the most difficult circumstances with the greatest players -- winning it means controlling yourself, managing your emotions, staying cool, not getting in a pissing contest with your caddie who, incidentally, quit.
answer: He always quits, he always comes back.

question: Nonetheless, from the mental aspect -- which is my domain -- you have regressed and are fumbling somewhere between delusion and denial.
answer: 'Regression, delusion, denial'? You gotta use all this psychological language?

question: I'm a psychologist. Hi, honey...
answer: I shot 65 -- parred the backside with a seven iron.

question: I think so...
answer: You ever shoot par with a seven iron?

question: It never occurred to me to try. C'mon, let's go. The car's over here....
answer: I'll bet you a thousand dollars against my car that I can beat you in any game -- any game, you name it -- with a seven iron.

question: This is ridiculous.
answer: You a coward? You gonna lay up the way you did at the Masters last year?

question: Take a minute to limber up, fine with me --
answer: Don't need to.

question: Take your jacket off?
answer: No, no, I'm fine.

question: Hey, honey...
answer: I heard you qualified for the Regionals -- why you so down?

question: I broke my clubs -- don't ask why, my caddie's pissed off at me, I lost my wheels in a sucker bet, and my shrink thinks I'm a fool -- 'cause I probably am...
answer: You're seeing a therapist?!

question: Yeah, what's wrong with that?
answer: Only way you'd ever go into therapy was if the shrink was a doll and you were trying to get her into the rack --

question: You're so shallow. The Good Doctor and I are dealing with my regression and denial --
answer: Oh, Tin Cup, what a crock. You got a hard-on.

question: I think three under will qualify. You need birdie. I could shit.
answer: A little more confidence there, Earl...

question: I wish Romeo was here. I ain't cut out to do this. I'm a spectator by nature. An observer. I'm a --
answer: Shut up and hand me the Big Dog.

question: You got it.
answer: The Force is with me, pods... We need this one big time, Earl, whattya think?

question: Looks straight to me.
answer: Straight?! Thing's a roller coaster breaks four ways and dies at the hole -- you're blind!

question: Actually, I am blind... 20-60 in one eye -- and that's the good eye...
answer: I got a blind caddie... just hold the stick, Earl -- and be sure to pull it out...

question: Doc? Doc? Earl, Earl -- the tape's jammed! She's abandoning me! Yeah, yeah... I'm flying solo now... I gotta make this putt. ... just pick the line, feel the speed -- bad timing, doc, Jesus... Like a million others you made in your life, Roy. Just see it going in. Just feel it... right in the back of the jar... just pull the goddamn trigger, you pussy... Pull the stick, Earl, pull it! Choking dogs die! Romes! You've come back! You shoulda been there, Romes, I drained a 30-foot snake to qualify! Earl gave me a straight read -- the thing broke half a dozen times -- missed ya, pods! Okay, don't talk to me -- but you're still my guy... It's a little late to be pissed off! We're in the Open! You and me! Awright, be that way -- -- say... has Molly been around?
answer: I knew you had the hots for her.

question: What's this? Garbo speaks? Of course I have the hots for her and I'm doing a damn good job of keeping things platonic and professional till I kick Simms' ass and show her I ain't who she thinks I am because, in fact, I am who she thinks I am but if I win the Open I won't be.
answer: Well, I don't think her nor me nor the God of Golf his self can keep you from blowing up in the Open...

question: I made it this far! I just got to hold it together for 72 more
answer: There's a lotta triple bogeys out there waiting to grab your ass.

question: You're complaining again! Romeo's back! Whining, bitching, pissed off -- you're my man!
answer: You didn't fall in love with Earl to be your caddie?

question: He was a wheezing heart attack waiting to happen -- cost me three strokes a side... I carried my bag the last four holes. I love ol' Earl but I need you.
answer: You don't love me?

question: I love you, too, God damn it!
answer: As much as Earl?

question: I don't know! Yes, yes, as much as Earl -- More than Earl!
answer: Am I special?

question: If you can remove the sexual connotations and overlay a golf theme, Romeo -- I am your Juliet.
answer: Muy bien, Julietta. In that case -- I am your caddy once again.

question: Podnuh. Awright... now that we got that bullshit outta the way, I'm gonna hit me some balls and start oilin' that sweet swing o' mine for the big boys... Nobody heard from Molly, eh?
answer: You got it bad, don't ya?

question: Somethin' about that chick... Hmmm... little chili dipper there...
answer: Be sure to do that in the Open.

question: Romeo!
answer: I'm watching.

question: It ain't no chili dipper.
answer: Yeah, boss, you got the 'S' word.

question: What am I doing wrong?
answer: Shanks are like a virus -- they just show up. Nobody can figure 'em out.

question: Romes! Something's terribly wrong. What's your guess?!
answer: It's the woman.

question: I thought you said it was a virus?
answer: A woman can have the same effect.

question: What do I do?
answer: Keep swinging...

question: Quit whining and get over here. We've got something for you.
answer: Unless it's a 'swing thought,' I'm not interested...

question: We're here to sponsor you in the
answer: But I got the shanks --

question: Yeah, and you obviously still have a hard-on for the doctor chick -- your face is all screwed up and tight like you haven't been laid in awhile --
answer: Is it really that obvious?

question: Roy? Anybody home? My God...
answer: Aarghh...

question: Roy...
answer: Dr. Griswold... The therapist laughs at her patient? Is that how it works? A man is laid bare before God and he's the butt of the cosmic joke?

question: I'm sorry, I just...
answer: Some of this shit might actually

question: Oh, Roy, Jesus... Quoting yourself, 'It is the paraphernalia for lost and desperate souls.'
answer: Well, God damn... a lost and desperate soul stands before you. I assume I have the confidentiality of doctor-client privilege in regards to this outfit?

question: Of course you do. What happened?
answer: I got the shanks.

question: Are you taking penicillin?
answer: It can't be treated! It's much worse than whatever you thought it was. There's a glitch in my swing.

question: So it's in Romeo's department?
answer: He thinks it's your department -- says it's a head thing.

question: Oh. Well. I just came over to congratulate you on the regionals and return your car -- David says he doesn't want it, just wanted to make a point with you -- But I suppose we could have a therapy session right here and now
answer: I don't want therapy. I want you.

question: Roy... I gotta get some air --
answer: Look at me -- Well, not right at the moment -- but listen to me. You're with the wrong guy. I'm the right guy. Everyone tells me my face is all screwed up tight as a drum 'cause I've been crazy about you from the day you showed up wearing this stupid stuff and the whole damn thing has both inspired me to get here on the verge of greatness yet it's also caused me to get the shanks which could humiliate me in front of a zillion people. Such is life. So dump that phony bastard and come to the Open in my corner -- you can delay your romantic urges, which I know are lurking in there among the excess of brain cells you possess -- until the appropriate time... Tell me you're not at least moderately attracted to me.

question: You have moments.
answer: Tell me which ones are my moments and I'll try to duplicate them.

question: This is a moment. You look great.
answer: Now?!

question: Utterly exposed, completely vulnerable, the inner child trying to get out.
answer: My inner child needs spanking.

question: You always liked that part about saddling up, the smell of leather
answer: C'mon, let's have a drink. Call it therapy. Charge me 75 an hour. Little Cuervo, little Freud...

question: Naw... I gotta go. Oh, I don't have a car, I need a ride.
answer: I know a spot along the river's great to watch the sunset?

question: Not tonight.
answer: 'Not tonight' means maybe some other night?

question: I didn't mean it like that.
answer: Consciously you didn't mean it like that -- but how about unconsciously, you're the expert, did you mean it unconsciously?

question: Unconsciously, Roy, I don't have a clue what I'm talking about.
answer: I feel we're making progress.

question: I do too. But I have no idea what it's progress towards... Good luck in the Open, Roy.
answer: Put your money on me, Doc, the odds are fabulous and God knows I'm overdue...

question: You got to relax, boss --
answer: Goin' to the U.S. Open with the shanks. Gonna be chili dipping my way around the course on worldwide television... sure, relax.

question: I'm gonna get rid of them shanks for ya. No hay problema.
answer: Molly and I are circling each other... I can feel it...

question: She the enemy, boss.
answer: Naw...

question: Well she wakin' up with the enemy -- same thing.
answer: Tell me something, Romes -- the absolute truth -- you think I can go 72 holes without falling apart. You heard me! I don't want no bullshit... do you think I can do it?

question: I don't know, boss, I just don't know.
answer: I bet this is the first Winnebago they ever saw here...

question: Look! Right there! Fred Couples... and Ray Floyd!
answer: Look at these balls. Brand new Titleists. Lookit 'em, every one a brand new Titleist. Sneak a few in the bag when you get a chance. We swipe enough free shit we might even pay for this fiasco.

question: You think it would be inappropriate to ask Ray Floyd for an autograph?
answer: I think it's a dead giveaway, Romes... but if I still got the shanks we're gonna be found out real fast...

question: Hit the seven iron. You never miss the seven...
answer: Good thought, Pods... Dollar bills... Who hit that shot? Anybody see?

question: A little thin, Boss.
answer: A little fucking thin?! I still got the shanks! Everybody's watching! Christ, Simms is here...

question: Maybe we should work on putting. Ya can't shank a putt.
answer: If you're the Mexican Mac O'Grady, Romes, you gotta figure out why I'm still shanking the ball. What's the problem? I'm catching it on the hosel, right? Moving my head? I'm laying off it, I'm pronating, I'm supinating, I'm clearing too early, I'm clearing too late, I'm off plane, I ain't dropping in -- oh, God, my swing feels like an unfolding lawn chair.

question: You got a virus in your brain. I
answer: Anything. Kill me now!

question: Put all your change in your right pocket. Very good. Now tie your left shoelace in a double knot. Esta bueno. Now, turn your hat around backwards and put a blue tee behind your right ear...
answer: I'll look like a fool.

question: What you think you look like hitting those squirrelly chili peppers up Freddy Couples' ass, eh? Do what I say or I quit.
answer: Okay, okay...

question: Perfect... now hit a seven iron into that tree over there. You're ready.
answer: How'd I do that?

question: You ain't thinking about shanking, you ain't thinking about the doctor lady, you ain't thinking period. You just lookin' like a fool and hittin' it pure -- your natural state.
answer: Fuck you.

question: You cured.
answer: That's it?

question: That's it. Your brain was getting in the way.
answer: That's rarely been a problem. What now?

question: Well, I should recommend you go work on your short game but I think it's better if you go get drunk instead.
answer: Get drunk?

question: Yeah. You always play better when you're wasted.
answer: It's three in the morning, Romes, what time I tee off?

question: Seven-o-five... first group off... Keep drinking, keep dancing...
answer: That's four hours from now?

question: You're drinking till five... c'mon, c'mon, have another -- Get you in shape -- Nothing like the sight of a finely-tuned athlete on the verge of greatness...
answer: No time for a bucket, eh?

question: Almost missed the starting time trying to get you off the floor, boss. You don't handle the hooch like you used to... I seen this hole on TV. Hit the big dog down the chute --
answer: No, I've learned my lesson. Gonna play it safe, smart, conservative. Fairways and greens. Hand me the two iron.

question: You sure?
answer: Thought of the day is -- `be humble.'

question: Eighty-three. Well, you humble now.
answer: Eleven bogeys and seven pars. I didn't make a three. I didn't make one goddam three all day.

question: You weren't trying to make threes. You were trying to avoid making thirteen.
answer: I was hungover!

question: Maybe that was a coaching error on my part.
answer: Thanks, amigo...

question: Got lucky out there... Hey, Tin Cup -- heard you put a monster number up there...
answer: Coulda been worse...

question: I played in the Pro-Am with some asshole movie star shot 82 here once... how did a great ball- striker like you, a `legend,' manage to shoot an 83?
answer: I missed a four foot putt on the eighteen for an 82, that's how...

question: This man still has a lot of good golf shots in his system --
answer: Molly, it's okay, go away... I don't need any attention right

question: David, I'll bet you a hundred dollars right now that Roy here can hit a ball -- -- from right here to... through that door to the patio...
answer: Molly, please...

question: I musta been blind thinking you were worth a shit, Simmsy! Drinks on me, boys! Helluva shot, Roy!
answer: Actually I thinned it a little or that pelican'd be flying around with a Titleist up his ass... I kinda shanked it, eh?

question: No, no, no... you were great...
answer: Tempo is everything...

question: Perfection's unobtainable...
answer: Mighta rushed it on the downswing...

question: Come over the top a little...
answer: Yeah... well, as Walter Hagen once said -- 'Sex and golf are the only two things you can be bad at and still enjoy...'

question: Nope.
answer: Carry, honey! Please! Carry!

question: What the hell. You ride 'er till she bucks you or you don't ride at all. I can save par from here.
answer: Up an' down...

question: This is for Venturi, up there in the booth, thinking I should lay up... Dollar bills... That's a long fucking ways. Gimme another ball.
answer: Roy...

question: What?
answer: It's a water hazard. You go up there and take a drop. Try to save par like you did yesterday.

question: What are the odds that Roy will win?
answer: Vegas has him at ten to one. They're sure he's gonna self-destruct.

question: Those sound good to me -- I want you to place a bet for me. Five thousand nine hundred dollars on Tin Cup to win.
answer: That's a bad idea, honey -- we love him, but he's gonna fuck- up --

question: Looking a little tight, Ledge.
answer: Musta got too much sleep last night. How you choking?

question: Just got one thought in my head. Ten under. That's my number.
answer: No one's ever been ten under for the Open, not even Nicklaus.

question: I didn't catch it all.
answer: Then you got to lay up.

question: So birdie wins it. You or me, Dave? He's laying up. Birdie to tie, eagle to win, and that gutless wonder's laying up.
answer: Par to tie, birdie to win... you lay up too, Roy. You can make birdie laying up.

question: You know something, Romeo? Eagle puts me ten under. No one's ever finished an Open ten under, not even Nicklaus.
answer: You don't need an eagle. Birdie wins, par ties. Hit the lay up. Hole a wedge for goddamn eagle.

question: This is everything, ain't it? This is the choice it comes down to. This is our immortality...
answer: No time to be thinkin' 'immortality,' Cup... time to be thinkin' 7 iron.

question: Oh no. This is what always happens. He's going for it.
answer: Go for it!

question: No! He just needs par to tie! Tell him to lay up! He listens to you!
answer: Go for it, Roy! Knock it on!

question: This is why we split up -- he always went for it...
answer: My problem is I've never been with

question: She's right, Pods, a drop and a stroke, up and down par -- we'll win it in sudden death.
answer: I nutted that thing. Little gust from the gods cost me...

question: Helluva move you put on that sucker, now let's get up there, take the drop, and make our par, tie Peter...
answer: I can make this shot.

question: Not now.
answer: Now. I'm playing it from here.
